title: Alonso's Penalty in the Australian GP 2024
text: ’ll start loading f1dataR package, preparing Python virtual environment (including installing FastF1). happens automatically call setup_fastf1(), see setup_fastf1 vignette information. Since crash occurred lap 57, ’ll download telemetry Alonso five previous laps compare Alonso fateful lap compared . ’ll also load Russell’s telemetry laps see reacts crash. Note use dplyr data manipulation. manipulations now make later plotting easier:
code: library(f1dataR) setup_fastf1() alo_telem <- dplyr::bind_rows(lapply(c(52:57), function(l) load_driver_telemetry(season = 2024, round = "Australia", session = "R", driver = "ALO", laps = l) %>% dplyr::mutate(lap = l))) rus_telem <- dplyr::bind_rows(lapply(c(52:57), function(l) load_driver_telemetry(season = 2024, round = "Australia", session = "R", driver = "RUS", laps = l) %>% dplyr::mutate(lap = l))) alo_telem$lap <- as.factor(alo_telem$lap) alo_telem$brake <- as.integer(alo_telem$brake) rus_telem$lap <- as.factor(rus_telem$lap) rus_telem$brake <- as.integer(rus_telem$brake)

title: Ergast Data Analysis
text: can look correlation starting (grid) position race finishing position. ’ll look Austrian Grand Prix 2020 analysis, particular reason, produced well mixed field. plot grid position (y axis) vs race finishing position (x axis) 2020 Austrian Grand Prix course, isn’t really interesting plot single race. Naturally expect better grid position yields better finish position, ’s much variation one race (including effect DNF) ’s weak correlation. can look whole season instead downloading sequentially list results. ’ll filter results remove didn’t finish race, also didn’t start grid (.e. started Pit Lane, grid = 0). plot grid position (y axis) vs race finishing position (x axis) 2020 Grands Prix expected, produces much stronger signal confirming earlier hypothesis.
code: library(ggplot2) # Load the data results <- load_results(2020, 1) %>%   mutate(     grid = as.numeric(grid),     position = as.numeric(position)   )  ggplot(results, aes(x = position, y = grid)) +   geom_point(color = "white") +   stat_smooth(method = "lm") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("2020 Austrian Grand Prix Grid - Finish Position") +   xlab("Finish Position") +   ylab("Grid Position") # Load the data results <- data.frame() for(i in seq_len(17)) {   Sys.sleep(1)   r <- load_results(2022, i)   results <- dplyr::bind_rows(results, r) }  results <- results %>%   mutate(     grid = as.numeric(grid),     position = as.numeric(position)   ) %>%   filter(status %in% c("Finished", "+1 Lap", "+2 Laps", "+6 Laps"), grid > 0)  ggplot(results, aes(y = position, x = grid)) +   geom_point(color = "white", alpha = 0.2) +   stat_smooth(method = "lm") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("2020 F1 Season Grid - Finish Position") +   ylab("Finish Position") +   xlab("Grid Position")

title: Ergast Data Analysis
text: Ergast contains points drivers’ constructors’ championship races end every round season. can pull season’s worth data compare driver pace throughout season, looking position total points accumulation. ’ll 2021, good competition throughout year P1. Driver ranking Grand Prix 2021 season may interesting total accumulation points. can change plot just little bit. Total points driver Grand Prix 2021 season
code: # Load the data points <- data.frame() for (rnd in seq_len(22)) {   p <- load_standings(season = 2021, round = rnd) %>%     mutate(round = rnd)   points <- rbind(points, p)   Sys.sleep(1) }  points <- points %>%   mutate(     position = as.numeric(position),     points = as.numeric(points)   )  # Plot the Results ggplot(points, aes(x = round, y = position, color = driver_id)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point(size = 1) +   ggtitle("Driver Position", subtitle = "Through 2021 season") +   xlab("Round #") +   ylab("Position") +   scale_y_reverse(breaks = seq_along(length(unique(points$position)))) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) # Plot the Results ggplot(points, aes(x = round, y = points, color = driver_id)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point(size = 1) +   ggtitle("Driver Points", subtitle = "Through 2021 season") +   xlab("Round #") +   ylab("Points") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE)

Laptime distributions drivers 2022 Saudi Arabian Grand Prix (racing laps )
code: # Load the laps data and select one driver (this time - Russell) rus <- load_laps(season = 2022, round = 2) %>%   filter(driver_id == "russell")  # Get Grand Prix Name racename <- load_schedule(2022) %>%   filter(round == 2) %>%   pull("race_name")  racename <- paste(racename, "2022")  # Plot the results ggplot(rus, aes(x = lap, y = time_sec)) +   geom_point(color = constructor_data %>% filter(constructor_id == "mercedes") %>% pull(constructor_color)) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("Russell Lap times through the Grand Prix", subtitle = racename) +   xlab("Lap Number") +   ylab("Lap Time (s)") # Load the laps data (cached!) and filter laps <- load_laps(season = 2022, round = 2) %>%   filter(time_sec < 105) %>%   group_by(driver_id) %>%   mutate(driver_avg = mean(time_sec)) %>%   ungroup() %>%   mutate(driver_id = factor(driver_id, unique(driver_id[order(driver_avg)])))  ggplot(laps, aes(x = driver_id, y = time_sec)) +   geom_violin(trim = FALSE) +   geom_boxplot(width = 0.1) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("Driver Lap Times", subtitle = paste("Racing Laps Only -", racename)) +   xlab("Driver ID") +   ylab("Lap Time (s)") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90))

title: Ergast Data Analysis
text: can compare qualifying times drivers Grand Prix. ’s naturally ways (pick driver’s fastest time, pick driver’s fastest time last session participated , etc), pros cons. Rerunning analysis different ways handling data produce different results! Gap Pole end qualifying 2023 Bahrain Grand Prix
code: # Load the Data quali <- load_quali(2023, 1)  # Process the Data quali <- quali %>%   summarize(t_min = min(q1_sec, q2_sec, q3_sec, na.rm = TRUE), .by = driver_id) %>%   mutate(     t_diff = t_min - min(t_min),     driver_id = factor(driver_id, unique(driver_id[order(-t_min)]))   )  # Plot the results ggplot(quali, aes(x = driver_id, y = t_diff)) +   geom_col() +   coord_flip() +   ggtitle("Bahrain 2023 Quali Time Comparison",     subtitle = paste("VER Pole time:", min(quali$t_min), "s")   ) +   ylab("Gap to Pole (s)") +   xlab("Driver ID") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE)

ℹ 687 more rows #> # ℹ 9 more variables: relative_distance <dbl>, status <chr>, x <dbl>, y <dbl>, z <dbl>, #> #   distance <dbl>, driver_ahead <chr>, distance_to_driver_ahead <dbl>, driver_code <chr> library(dplyr) library(ggplot2)  lec <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "LEC", laps = "fastest") %>%   head(300)  ggplot(lec, aes(distance, throttle)) +   geom_line() +   theme_minimal() ham <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "HAM", laps = "fastest") %>%   head(300)  per <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "PER", laps = "fastest") %>%   head(300)  data <- bind_rows(lec, ham, per)  ggplot(data, aes(distance, throttle, color = driver_code)) +   geom_line() +   theme_minimal()

title: Introduction
text: Now let’s look complete analysis. want visualize lap time change time (tyre age) Pérez every compound used Spanish GP. Average laptime per tyre type age Spanish Grand Prix 2023 Now let’s visualize portion track Verstappen throttle 100% open 2023 Canadian GP. Note ’ll pass plot helper function correct_track_ratio() ensure plotted track correct dimensions (tweaks pretty plotting). Alternatively, can call ggplot2::coord_fixed() building track plots ensure x & y ratios equal. Verstappen fastest lab Canadian Grand Prix 2023, showing full throttle sections simpler visualization let’s look average time took team pit round 4 2023. load pit data, results data (extract driver + team combos), read constructor data get colors plot. Note time difference pit entry exit, stopped time. Average time pits team 2023 Azerbaijan Grand Prix
code: laps <- load_session_laps(2023, "Spain") %>%   filter(driver == "PER") %>%   group_by(compound) %>%   # Remove in and out laps   filter(tyre_life != 1 & tyre_life != max(tyre_life)) %>%   ungroup()  ggplot(laps, aes(tyre_life, lap_time, color = compound)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   labs(     color = "Tyre Compound",     y = "Lap Time (Seconds)",     x = "Tyre Life (Laps)"   ) +   scale_color_manual(     values = c("white", "yellow", "red")   ) +   scale_y_continuous(breaks = seq(75, 85, 1)) +   scale_x_continuous(breaks = seq(2, 26, 4)) ver_can <- load_driver_telemetry(   season = 2023,   round = "Canada",   driver = "VER",   laps = "fastest" ) %>%   mutate(open_throttle = ifelse(throttle == 100, "Yes", "No"))  throttle_plot <- ggplot(ver_can, aes(x, y, color = as.factor(open_throttle), group = NA)) +   geom_path(linewidth = 4, lineend = "round") +   scale_color_manual(values = c("white", "red")) +   theme_dark_f1() +   labs(     title = "Verstappen Flat Out",     subtitle = "Canada 2023 | Fastest Lap",     color = "Throttle 100%"   )  correct_track_ratio(throttle_plot) pit_data <- load_pitstops(2023, 4)  driver_team <- load_results(2023, 4) %>%   select(driver_id, constructor_id)  pit_constructor <- pit_data %>%   left_join(driver_team, by = "driver_id") %>%   group_by(constructor_id) %>%   summarise(pit_time = mean(as.numeric(duration)))  pit_constructor$constructor_color <- sapply(pit_constructor$constructor_id, get_team_color, season = 2023, round = 4, USE.NAMES = FALSE)  pit_constructor$team_name <- sapply(pit_constructor$constructor_id, get_team_name, season = 2023, short = TRUE, USE.NAMES = FALSE)  ggplot(pit_constructor, aes(x = team_name, y = pit_time, fill = team_name)) +   geom_bar(stat = "identity", fill = pit_constructor$constructor_color) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   theme(     legend.position = "none"   ) +   labs(     x = "Constructor",     y = "Average Pit Time (seconds)"   ) +   ggtitle("Average time in pit lane for each team", subtitle = "Azerbaijan Grand Prix 2023")

title: Jolpica Data Analysis
text: Jolpica contains points drivers’ constructors’ championship races end every round season. can pull season’s worth data compare driver pace throughout season, looking position total points accumulation. ’ll 2021, good competition throughout year P1. Driver ranking Grand Prix 2021 season may interesting total accumulation points. can change plot just little bit. Total points driver Grand Prix 2021 season bit hard read use driver_id values aren’t pretty plot. can use FastF1 look-functions improve graphics (recalling Kubica raced Alfa Romeo races 13 & 14 mid-season). ’ll first build data.frame drivers styles season, join points data.frame generate driver abbreviations Jolpica driver_id. data graphical label information added, can remake plots: Remade points plot driver Grand Prix 2021 season, better driver names colors
code: # Load the data points <- data.frame() for (rnd in seq_len(22)) {   p <- load_standings(season = 2021, round = rnd) %>%     mutate(round = rnd)   points <- rbind(points, p)   Sys.sleep(1) }  points <- points %>%   mutate(     position = as.numeric(position),     points = as.numeric(points)   )  # Plot the Results ggplot(points, aes(x = round, y = position, color = driver_id)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point(size = 1) +   ggtitle("Driver Position", subtitle = "Through 2021 season") +   xlab("Round #") +   ylab("Position") +   scale_y_reverse(breaks = seq_along(length(unique(points$position)))) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range (`geom_line()`). #> Warning: Removed 2 rows containing missing values or values outside the scale range #> (`geom_point()`). # Plot the Results ggplot(points, aes(x = round, y = points, color = driver_id)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point(size = 1) +   ggtitle("Driver Points", subtitle = "Through 2021 season") +   xlab("Round #") +   ylab("Points") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) driver_style <- rbind(   get_session_drivers_and_teams(2021, round = 1),   get_session_drivers_and_teams(2021, round = 13) ) %>%   unique()  driver_style$linestyle <- driver_style$marker <- driver_style$color <- driver_style$abbreviation <- NA  for (i in seq_along(driver_style$name)) {   if (driver_style$name[i] == "Robert Kubica") {     # Manually handling Kubica     style <- get_driver_style(driver_style$name[i], season = 2021, round = 13)     driver_style$color[i] <- style$color     driver_style$marker[i] <- 2     driver_style$linestyle[i] <- "dotted"     driver_style$abbreviation[i] <- style$abbreviation   } else {     style <- get_driver_style(driver_style$name[i], season = 2021, round = 1)     driver_style$color[i] <- style$color     driver_style$marker[i] <- style$marker     driver_style$linestyle[i] <- style$linestyle     driver_style$abbreviation[i] <- style$abbreviation   } }  color_values <- driver_style$color names(color_values) <- driver_style$abbreviation  marker_values <- driver_style$marker names(marker_values) <- driver_style$abbreviation  linestyle_values <- driver_style$linestyle names(linestyle_values) <- driver_style$abbreviation  points <- dplyr::left_join(points, load_drivers(2021)[, c("driver_id", "code")], by = "driver_id") ggplot(points, aes(x = round, y = points, color = code, shape = code, linetype = code)) +   geom_line() +   geom_point() +   scale_color_manual(name = "Driver", values = color_values, aesthetics = c("color", "fill")) +   scale_shape_manual(name = "Driver", values = marker_values) +   scale_linetype_manual(name = "Driver", values = linestyle_values) +   ggtitle("Driver Points", subtitle = "Through 2021 season") +   xlab("Round #") +   ylab("Points") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE)

Note safety car occurred around lap 8. data, can also visualize driver’s laptimes violin plots. ’ll trim laptimes exclude anything 100 seconds make variation lap time easier see (.e. show racing laps). can recycle color values produced . Laptime distributions drivers 2021 Spanish Grand Prix (racing laps )
code: # Load the laps data and select one driver (this time - Russell) bot <- load_laps(season = 2021, round = 4) %>%   filter(driver_id == "bottas")  # Get Grand Prix Name racename <- load_schedule(2021) %>%   filter(round == 4) %>%   pull("race_name")  racename <- paste(racename, "2021")  # Plot the results ggplot(bot, aes(x = lap, y = time_sec)) +   geom_point(color = get_driver_color("Bottas", 2021, 4)) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("Bottas Lap times through the Grand Prix", subtitle = racename) +   xlab("Lap Number") +   ylab("Lap Time (s)") # Load the laps data (cached!) and filter laps <- load_laps(season = 2021, round = 4) %>%   filter(time_sec < 100) %>%   group_by(driver_id) %>%   mutate(driver_avg = mean(time_sec)) %>%   ungroup() %>%   left_join(load_drivers(2021)[, c("driver_id", "code")], by = "driver_id") %>%   mutate(code = factor(code, unique(code[order(driver_avg)])))  ggplot(laps, aes(x = code, y = time_sec, color = code, fill = code)) +   geom_violin(trim = FALSE) +   scale_color_manual("Driver", values = color_values, aesthetics = c("color", "fill")) +   geom_boxplot(width = 0.1, color = "black", fill = "white", outlier.shape = NA) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("Driver Lap Times", subtitle = paste("Racing Laps Only -", racename)) +   xlab("Driver ID") +   ylab("Lap Time (s)") +   theme(axis.text.x = element_text(angle = 90), legend.position = "")

title: Jolpica Data Analysis
text: can compare qualifying times drivers Grand Prix. ’s naturally ways (pick driver’s fastest time, pick driver’s fastest time last session participated , etc), pros cons. Rerunning analysis different ways handling data produce different results! Gap Pole end qualifying 2021 Styrian Grand Prix
code: # Load the Data quali <- load_quali(2021, 8)  # Get Grand Prix Name racename <- load_schedule(2021) %>%   filter(round == 8) %>%   pull("race_name")  # Process the Data quali <- quali %>%   summarize(t_min = min(q1_sec, q2_sec, q3_sec, na.rm = TRUE), .by = driver_id) %>%   mutate(t_diff = t_min - min(t_min)) %>%   left_join(load_drivers(2021)[, c("driver_id", "code")], by = "driver_id") %>%   mutate(code = factor(code, unique(code[order(-t_min)])))  # Plot the results ggplot(quali, aes(x = code, y = t_diff, color = code, fill = code)) +   geom_col() +   coord_flip() +   ggtitle(paste0(racename, " 2021 Quali Time Comparison"),     subtitle = paste("VER Pole time:", min(quali$t_min), "s")   ) +   scale_color_manual(values = color_values, aesthetics = c("fill", "color")) +   ylab("Gap to Pole (s)") +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   theme(legend.position = "")

title: Plotting with FastF1 Circuit Information
text: Introduction vignette, ’ll start working telemetry data. demonstrate addition turn information, ’ll start plotting speed telemetry three drivers Speed Distance Leclerc, Hamilton Perez qualifying best laps Now, add corner numbers plot like , ’ll retrieve FastF1. Now can add indicators previous plot: Speed distance plot , turn numbres added course, labels overlap slightly turns close together (1-3, 5-7, 9-10, 14-15). packages ggrepel can handle situations better, point demonstration.
code: lec <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "LEC", laps = "fastest") ham <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "HAM", laps = "fastest") per <- load_driver_telemetry(2022, 1, "Q", driver = "PER", laps = "fastest")  telem <- bind_rows(lec, ham, per) %>%   select(rpm, speed, n_gear, throttle, brake, drs, distance, time, driver_code) %>%   mutate(drs = ifelse(drs == 12, 1, 0))  drivercolours <- c(   "LEC" = get_driver_color("LEC", 2022, 1),   "HAM" = get_driver_color("HAM", 2022, 1),   "PER" = get_driver_color("PER", 2022, 1) ) telem_plot_speed <- ggplot(telem, aes(x = distance, y = speed, color = driver_code)) +   geom_path() +   scale_color_manual(values = drivercolours) +   theme_dark_f1(axis_marks = TRUE) +   ggtitle("2022 Bahrain Grand Prix Qualifying Telemetry", subtitle = "Speed vs Distance in lap") +   xlab("Distance (m)") +   ylab("Speed") +   labs(color = "Driver")  telem_plot_speed bahrain_circuit <- load_circuit_details(2022, 1) bahrain_corners <- bahrain_circuit$corners  speedmax <- max(telem$speed, na.rm = TRUE) speedmin <- min(telem$speed, na.rm = TRUE) telem_plot_speed +   geom_vline(xintercept = bahrain_corners$distance, linetype = "longdash", color = "#646464") +   geom_label(data = bahrain_corners, aes(     label = paste0(number, letter),     y = speedmin - 10,     x = distance,     color = "#9A9A9A"   ), show.legend = FALSE)

title: Plotting with FastF1 Circuit Information
text: Similar plotting turn numbers telemetry, can add annotations typical track plot. ’ll work 2022 Silverstone (British Grand Prix) plot. Lets’ start getting data: Now ’ll plot . Look bottom code see addition labels. Gear selected Verstappen Silverstone fastest qualifying lap Like , plot issues overlap. time, beyond using ggrepel, data provided move labels ‘pretty’ way. data returned get_circuit_data() includes extra column (angle) can used determine adequate shift angle label. data, careful math, can move labels want . new label x y points calculated, can re-plot labels slightly offset track. Plot showing gear use Vertappen around Silversone, corner labels applied exploration (including label repelling) left reader.
code: ver <- load_driver_telemetry(season = 2022, round = "Silverstone", session = "Q", driver = "VER", laps = "fastest") silverstone_circuit <- load_circuit_details(season = 2022, round = "Silverstone") gear_plot <- ggplot(ver, aes(x, y, color = as.factor(n_gear), group = NA)) +   geom_path(linewidth = 4, lineend = "round") +   ggplot2::scale_color_manual(     name = "Gear",     values = c(       "1" = "#BC3C29", "2" = "#0072B5", "3" = "#E18727", "4" = "#20854E",       "5" = "#7876B1", "6" = "#6F99AD", "7" = "#FFDC91", "8" = "#EE4C97"     ),     aesthetics = c("color", "fill")   ) +   theme_dark_f1() +   labs(     title = "British Grand Prix 2022",     subtitle = "Gear in use by Verstappen in Quali",     color = "Gear"   ) labelled_gear_plot <- gear_plot +   geom_label(data = silverstone_circuit$corners, aes(     label = paste0(number, letter),     y = y,     x = x,     color = "#9A9A9A"   ), show.legend = FALSE)  correct_track_ratio(labelled_gear_plot) labelx <- function(x, angle, distance = 750) {   angle <- angle * pi / 180   return(cos(angle) * distance + x) } labely <- function(y, angle, distance = 750) {   angle <- angle * pi / 180   return(sin(angle) * distance + y) }  silverstone_circuit$corners$labx <- labelx(silverstone_circuit$corners$x, silverstone_circuit$corners$angle) silverstone_circuit$corners$laby <- labely(silverstone_circuit$corners$y, silverstone_circuit$corners$angle) labelled_gear_plot2 <- gear_plot +   geom_label(data = silverstone_circuit$corners, aes(     label = paste0(silverstone_circuit$corners$number, silverstone_circuit$corners$letter),     y = silverstone_circuit$corners$laby,     x = silverstone_circuit$corners$labx,     color = "white",   ), size = 3, label.padding = unit(0.15, "lines"), show.legend = FALSE)  correct_track_ratio(labelled_gear_plot2)

title: Driver & Team Look-ups — driver_team_lookup
text: functions provide ability look-drivers teams (match two) given races seasons. get_driver_abbreviation() looks driver abbreviation (typically 3 letters) used provided season. get_team_name() looks officially recorded team name based fuzzy matching supplied string. fairly inconsistent, example, "Haas" recorded "Haas F1 Team", sponsor names recorded names indicating 'F1 Team' –  "RB" recorded "RB" "Visa Cash App RB F1 Team". short = TRUE short form team provided ("Haas" instead "Haas F1 Team"). get_driver_name() looks driver's full name based fuzzy matching supplied string. driver participated session (season, round, session) match properly. full-time drivers easy, rookies test FP1 important note. get_drivers_by_team() looks team's drivers provided race session (season, round, session). looking practice rookies, typically participate session = FP1. get_team_by_driver() looks team specified driver (specified race event). get_session_drivers_and_teams() returns data frame drivers team provided session.

title: Load Circuit Information — load_circuit_details
text: Loads circuit details specific race session. Note different track layouts used circuits depending year race. Useful visualizing annotating data. Contains information corners, marshal_lights marshal_sectors. set track marker types returned tibble. Also returns angle (degrees) indicate amount rotation telemetry visually align two. information data provided (uses) can seen https://docs.fastf1.dev/circuit_info.html#fastf1.mvapi.CircuitInfo.corners Note exposition FastF1 data. , caching recommended (default behavior). Cache directory can set setting option(f1dataR.cache = [cache dir]), default current working directory. trouble errors mentioning 'fastf1' 'get_fastf1_version()' read 'Setup FastF1 Connection vignette (run vignette('setup_fastf1', 'f1dataR')).

text: season number 2018 current season. Defaults current season. round number 1 23 (depending season selected). Also accepts race name. log_level Detail logging fastf1 displayed. Choice : 'DEBUG', 'INFO', 'WARNING', 'ERROR' 'CRITICAL'. See fastf1 documentation.

title: Load Circuit Information — load_circuit_details
text: list tibbles containing corner number, marshall post number, marshall segment, plus numeric value rotational offset data compared telemetry data. tibbles following structure: x y specify position track map number number corner. Letter optionally used differentiate corners number circuits, e.g. “2A”. angle angle degrees, used visually offset marker’s placement track map logical direction (usually orthogonal track). distance location marker distance start/finish line.

title: Load Telemetry Data for a Driver — load_driver_telemetry
text: Receives season, race number, driver code, optional fastest lap argument output car telemetry selected situation. Example usage code can seen Introduction vignette (run vignette('introduction', 'f1dataR') read). Multiple drivers' telemetry can appended one data frame user. trouble errors mentioning 'fastf1' 'get_fastf1_version()' read "Setup FastF1 Connection" vignette (run vignette('setup_fastf1', 'f1dataR')).

title: Load Telemetry Data for a Driver — load_driver_telemetry
code: load_driver_telemetry(   season = get_current_season(),   round = 1,   session = "R",   driver,   laps = "fastest",   log_level = "WARNING",   race = lifecycle::deprecated(),   fastest_only = lifecycle::deprecated() )

title: Load Telemetry Data for a Driver — load_driver_telemetry
text: season number 2018 current season (defaults current season). round number 1 23 (depending season selected). Also accepts race name. session code session load Options 'FP1', 'FP2', 'FP3', 'Q', 'S', 'SS', 'SQ', 'R'. Default 'R', refers Race. driver three letter driver code (see load_drivers() list) laps lap's telemetry return. One integer lap number (<= total laps race), fastest, . Note integer lap choice requires fastf1 version 3.0 greater. log_level Detail logging fastf1 displayed. Choice : 'DEBUG', 'INFO', 'WARNING', 'ERROR' 'CRITICAL'. See fastf1 documentation. race race longer supported, use round. fastest_only fastest_only longer supported, indicated preferred laps laps.

title: Load Telemetry Data for a Driver — load_driver_telemetry
text: tibble telemetry data selected driver/session.

title: f1dataR (development version)
text: Forced fail-Ergast Jolpica (still deprecated ‘warn’ level). Fixed pre-season bug Jolpica API missing column load_season(). Fixed bug resulting change API 2025 season - Thanks @appiehappie999 (#277)

title: f1dataR 2.0.0
text: CRAN release: 2025-03-01 Deprecated Ergast moved Jolpica API Ergast Functions. breaking change code syntax, documentation changes significantly reflect new major version appropriate. (#268) Bugfix plot_fastest(). Bugfix load_results() pagination - Thanks @awanderingspirit. (#272) Bugfix README. (#267)

title: f1dataR 1.6.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-08-27 Soft deprecates FastF1 v < 3.4.0, hard deprecates FastF1 v < 3.1.0. Added functions get driver graphic style & team colors FastF1. See get_driver_style(), get_driver_color(), get_team_color() get_driver_color_map() (aliases colour). Added functions look-ups driver & team information seasons/sessions. See get_driver_abbreviation(), get_driver_name(), get_team_by_driver(), get_team_name(), get_drivers_by_team(). Removed constructor_data object package vignettes, readme, examples, etc. Expanded vignettes improve graphics & demonstrate lookups. Removed usethis Suggests (needed changing data) Updated tests avoid API failure 2022 season & better skip--CRAN internet resources Updated minimum R 3.5.0, reflecting imported package requirements.

title: f1dataR 1.5.3
text: CRAN release: 2024-05-01 Enabled Sprint Qualifying “SQ” session type line FastF1 v3.3.5.

title: f1dataR 1.5.2
text: CRAN release: 2024-04-15 Modified testing satisfy CRAN requirements. Added vignette looking telemetry plots Alonso’s 2024 Australia penalty.

title: f1dataR 1.5.1
text: CRAN release: 2024-03-12 Added (soft) deprecation warning Ergast functions advance Ergast API defunct less 12 months. Deprecated support FastF1 v < 3.1.0. Older FastF1 versions support functions use may return different values data retrieval calculation functions. Forcing use --date FastF1 allows simpler bugfixes code updates. (#198) Removed Ergast check get_current_season() (#227) Improved messaging users regarding updating FastF1 (#226) Named items list returned load_circuit_details() Changed way correct_track_ratio() works. Visually results , now labels/annotations added ggplot kept right spot. Added Vignette describing load_circuit_details() usage. Code improvements (better handle variation Ergast response, better handle Ergast connection failures) (#228) Testing improvements validate handling internet failures (#228) Upgraded use httptest2 testing -internet scenarios (affect package performance) Code cleanup (removed old inaccessible code, centralized repeated steps functions, etc.)

title: f1dataR 1.5.0
text: CRAN release: 2024-01-25 Added load_circuit_details (#210) Strengthened package testing (#212, #216) Bugfixes (#216)

title: f1dataR 1.4.1
text: CRAN release: 2023-11-13 Fixed bug cache options (#194, #195, #197) Fixed build bug Began deprecation support FastF1 v < 3.1.0

title: f1dataR 1.4.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-10-03 Fully deprecated round fastest_only arguments Updated plot_fastest() use correct_track_ratio() Ensured cache option default ("memory") (#181, #183) Virtualenv Conda environment management user now

title: f1dataR 1.3.0
text: CRAN release: 2023-08-17 Updated documentation per requirements CRAN review Changed caching behavior per requirements CRAN review. previously set cache directory options("f1dataR.cache" = [dir]) change. previously specified cache directory, package used use result getwd(), can force directory. New users can specify default file cache location setting options("f1dataR.cache" = "filesystem") specify (existing) directory setting option. Cache otherwise use memory default end R session 24h (whichever comes first). Caching can turned setting option “”
